Audiovisual Recordings Bedford-Stuyvesant Clinics, Part 2 AV83 2 83 1962 March 13 WNYU (Radio station : New York, N.Y.). Scope and Contents

This recording appears to be part two of the recording "Urban League Presents: Bedford-Stuyvesant Looks to Psychiatric Needs" on AV523. It is unclear whether this recording ever aired on WNYU.

 Related Material

This tape is related to materials in RG 39.5, Records of WNYU (Radio Station: New York, N.Y.). Also see ref140 (AV523): Urban League Presents: Bedford-Stuyvesant Looks to Psychiatric Needs in AV collection

 Kennedy, John F., (John Fitzgerald), 1917-1963 Pipes and Pedals of New York AV115 3 115 1.0 sound tape reels 28:38 1962 August 6 1/4" audio tape reel WNYU (Radio station : New York, N.Y.). Related Material

This tape is related to materials in RG 39.5, Records of WNYU (Radio Station: New York, N.Y.).

 Scope and Contents

This recording concerns the history of organ instruments. It was created by the Documentary Unit of the Communications Arts Group and broadcasted on WNYU. The host was Walt Michaels and the organist player featured on the recording is Dick Wolitoch.

 Physical/Technical notes

Recorded on Scotch Magnetic Tape (3M) at 7 1/2 IPS.

 The Irish Muse: An Evening of Readings New York University Producer: Elisa Guarino AV1679 44 1679 1.0 videocassettes (VHS) 1993 April 27 Guarino, Elisa Various recordings of and relating to Richard Nixon AV1848 48 1848 1.0 videoreels (1/2 inch) 8 August 1974 Scope and Contents

This recording includes the complete resignation speech of former U.S. President Richard Nixon, as well as clips from NBC, CBS, and ABC news coverage of the event.

 Provenance

This recording was donated by the Office of Media Production.

 Nixon, Richard M., (Richard Milhous), 1913-1994 Various recordings of footage from the Richard Nixon presidency AV1849 48 1849 1.0 videoreels (1/2 inch) 8 August 1974 Scope and Contents

This recording includes footage of Richard Nixon during his presidency, as well as interviews with Bella Abzug, Gabe Pressman, and New York University School of Law Dean Robert McKay. It also includes footage of Gerald Ford being sworn in as Vice President, and the appointment of Henry Kissinger as Secretary of State.

 Provenance

This recording was donated by the Office of Media Production.

 Marshall McLuhan untitled AV4448 118 4448 1.0 videocassettes Scope and Contents

The video quality of this disc is grainy and the volume is makes it difficult to hear exactly what people are saying The setting is a lecture hall Where McLuhan, Nevitt, and various other people are seated facing an audience. In his discussion there is a reference to being at a conference at the School of Dentistry but nothing is truly specified. The men, mainly McLuhan, discuss how environment effects and is effected by technology while the actual technology is incidental. They further talk about technological breakthroughs and how humans perceive it. Intellectual decline from over stimulation from technology creating a "goal-less" child who is more interested in role playing rather than true decision making thanks to television and radio. Most of the discussion is based on McLuahn's "Laws of Media" which is a four part tetrad of things that share an "interlocking nature" when humans consume media. The four parts are Enhance, Reverse, Retrieve, Obsolescence. The film cuts out frequently and ends abruptly.

 Marshall McLuhan Ecology Program AV4451 118 4451 1.0 reel Access copy

Access copy available on CD: ACCESS 1:21

 Scope and Contents

No title of event given or visible. The video quality of this disk is clear and the people speaking within the room are relatively easy to hear and comprehend especially when McLuhan speaks.The tape starts in the middle of a group discussion. The setting is in an office with a large table. The audience participates, asking McLuhan questions and receiving answers from him. The majority of the discussion is based on McLuhans "Laws of Media" which is a four part tetrad of things that share an "interlocking nature" when humans consume media. The four parts are Enhance, Reverse, Retrieve, Obsolescence. His discussion raises concern on mans responsibility for technologies and its effect on humans. He argues that we need studies about technology in order to shape them properly for consumption. Part of his argument is about adverting in the American home as opposed to foreign advertising which is much less prevalent in private lives. He also discusses the effects of politicians becoming visually and verbally known by the general public. The discussion ends with the conclusion that our current media is an open game meaning that nothing is finalized. McLuhan concludes that he does not believe there is a solidified answer to his questions. Instead he views it as a continued exploration. The film ends with questions from the audience where McLuhan fields questions, takes business cards, and hands back his portable mic he was using.

Alumni Fun was a CBS game show that aired between 1963 and 1966. Alumni from colleges and universities across the United States competed to win money for scholarships. Each show featured two teams of three participants each; they answered questions in a variety of categories to receive points. Teams would continue in competition until defeated.

This episode features NYU competing against the University of Colorado.
